welcome to conversations with leaders

and i'm very excited to be joined by don

corporate vice president of global

at adp don thank you for joining us
today and welcome
can you please uh introduce yourself

yeah for sure and uh pleased to be here
so i'm don weinstein i
am responsible for all of adp's global
products as well as
internal technology worldwide it's it's
a little bit of an unusual dual role but
effectively anything and everything that
has to do with technology
runs through my office adp
we're the world's largest payroll and
human capital management
provider we provide service to over 860
clients in more than 140 countries
and we pay more than 40 million people
worldwide and so chances are if you know
us well or not but
chances are you've been paid by adp at
some point
in your career so pleasure to be with
here and
look forward to the conversation well
thank you uh don for joining us today
and that's a
fascinating scale of what adp does
now if we look back at last year and how
pandemic unfolded
from the initial onset to just the need
to quickly pivot to working from home
to then really reimagining maybe part of
your business processes
in how you help your customers adopt to
the new normal
and now probably some of the companies
are thinking about bringing employees
safely back to work in some cases uh
how did you lead through that change
could you please walk us through how you
responded to these different phases
yeah and and you definitely hit all the
major phases there
i think the early days were a mad
scramble
like many organizations uh here in the
u.s i think we'd had a long tran
uh tradition of folks you know working
either
part time remotely or or at least
remoting in but
you know as a global organization with
half of our workforce outside the u.s
we had to quickly pivot and enable our
our associates
in our entire organization to become a
virtual organization
and that meant scrambling around trying
to procure
equipment in some cases where we
couldn't get laptops we would buy
as many wireless cards as we could and
stuff them into associate desktops so
they could take those homes
uh take those home with them and then of
course we we never really designed our
network
in a way to have our entire 60 000
person global workforce
uh remoting in so we had to boost our
vpn capacity on the fly
in many cases we were backhauling
traffic around the world
just to take advantage of time zone
differences
and be able to uh to balance out uh
overall capacity
through it all you know the most
important thing that we used from
from i would say a management uh
technique in order to
keep the operation moving to keep our
associates
engaged and focused was just about
increasing
communications but the second thing i
think that was really critical
in all of this was to make sure that we
were conveying
confidence and trust to the workforce
you know at adp we have our our adp
research institute that does a lot of
of really groundbreaking studies in the
field of people at work and workforce
engagement
like and we just completed a global
resiliency study
that that looked at you know the impact
of the pandemic
on the resiliency of the workforce and
one of the findings that came out of
that not surprisingly was that
trust in leadership was one of the
critical driving factors
for workers being more engaged and more
resilient through the pandemic
and in many cases what that boiled down
to was just
just being honest with folks not trying
to
make promises that you couldn't fulfill
but
giving folks a sense that hey when
leadership says something they're going
to commit to it
they're going to do it and you know for
us that meant not trying to make
specific predictions around
hey you know we think we're going to be
back in the office three months from now
six months from now 12 months from now
because nobody really knew
but rather saying hey here's what we're
going to do this this week
or here's what the priorities are for
this day making those commitments and
sticking to them
really was a critical tool for just
keeping the entire workforce engaged
and focused through the transition
that's uh that's incredible
uh don uh i i really love the fact that
you highlighted how important the
communication is
in increasing the frequency of
communication is especially in the time
of uncertainty uh
like we uh we have been experiencing

can you tell us a little bit more about
how how do you see
transparency and trust and how do you

yeah well it's a it's a big area of
focus for us you know
adp we sit on on multiple petabytes
worth of data
as i mentioned you know when you when
you're paying 40 million people every
pay period and then
with the turnover in the workforce we'll
see many many more than that
over the course of a year so we have
incredible uh
data and data assets but the data that
we have
is obviously sometimes quite sensitive
in terms of individuals pay
or other kinds of personally
identifiable information so
of course first and foremost um
we create uh we fully anonymize and then
aggregate the the data that uh that we
do use
uh we have kind of a separation of
church and state if you
if you would between production system
data
and that what goes into our analytics
and so that we don't have any teams
crossing the uh the streams there
but we try and take it a step further
and so uh by way of example
uh recently we launched an ai ethics
board
internally to provide governance and
oversight into our our use of data
and in in particular it's a blended
board where we have
internal resources including our our
general counsel and our chief

externals
to sit on the ai ethics board so we have
an external council as well as someone
from the field of academia
to provide that that outside in
checkpoint
on what we're doing absolutely and such
an important point uh
that you uh bring up there around

bringing in external
uh thought leadership uh an external set
of eyes as well
helping you define that uh i'm i'm
pretty sure a lot of our executives who
are listening to this
uh will be interested in learning a
little bit more could you share a little
bit more about the ai ethics board and
and how it functions and some of the
charter and the kind of work that it
does
yeah absolutely and i think the first
thing that we did is
uh back to your point about transparency
we published this all
externally on our adp.com website
because you know really not very
transparent to have
an ai ethics board or a set of
principals uh
that that we keep to ourselves closed
off so the ai ethics board
it meets quarterly and it has governance
and review
in particular over any kind of new
models that we're developing
so they can weigh in early in that
development process and identify
potential blind spots you know even in
some cases
it's just about making sure we we have
good
guideposts in terms of how far we do or
don't want to go
up that spectrum of of providing data
to insights even to recommendations but
maybe
not necessarily uh all the way to to the
decision side
i'll give you a very recent example of
it something that we we launched
uh quite quite recently is uh we have a
a sizable business providing retirement
services 401k plans
particularly to small and mid-sized
employers
and what we what we recently launched is
just an algorithm around people like you
and what we find sometimes is investors
especially
ones who are new to the world investing
sometimes
you know they'll become i'll say even
paralyzed by fear into inaction
or maybe making you know not the best
choices and so what we've done now is
just
used a machine learning algorithm
to identify cohorts of investors
and then we can match that to say look
if you're coming in new here's what
other people like you
are doing here is how they are investing
it's one of the core principles that we
adhere to in our approach to ai ethics
and one of the things we really think
differentiates us is by saying hey it's
not that i'm going to recommend this
fund to you
and you have no idea why instead i can
say
well look based on these demographic
characteristics that you've given to us
which is your age
your marital status your family status
we know something about your income
i can break you into a cohort of similar
situated people
and say here's what people like you
here's how they are
investing allow you to make the decision
we offer up the data very transparently
and i think that's a good balance of
providing
insights to individuals that's helping
them make better decisions
but doing it in a very transparent
manner and that's the type of topic
that we brought to the ai ethics board
and wrestled around like how far up that
continuum do we feel comfortable pushing
it's a wonderful example of uh
using sort of data and machine learning
not just to throw up the recommendation
but actually throwing light into on what
basis you're providing that
recommendation
which i think goes back to your point
about earning customer trust
uh and bringing the transparency so don
one of the
change that happened last year was
around regulation
uh in response to pandemic there was
just a record pace of change
uh in which regulations came out and

march april time frame
uh and with adb supporting so many

tell us a little bit about uh how you
responded to that amount of change in

and help your customers remain compliant
yeah it was it was unprecedented as i
mentioned i've been i've been with adp
15 years it's like nothing i've i've
ever seen in my
uh tenure here not just about the the
volume of regulation
but the speed uh with which it was
coming because obviously
events were were unfolding very rapidly
uh
during the uh the early phases of the
pandemic
uh the way it typically works uh in our
business
is uh when there are changes to tax or
employment laws
they're usually made prospectively that
would start
will make the law now and it will take
effect the next quarter
or maybe even the next year but because
of what was happening on the ground
uh the these changes were made
retrospectively
so for instance uh the ffcra act
was passed the last week of march for
the quarter ending march
so unlike a usual period where okay we
see the new law
we interpret it maybe we have a period
where we ask questions back and forth
with the government then we code the
changes in and test them and and they're
ready to go for the next quarter
this one came out on a friday and then
by the following week it had already
flipped over to the new quarter
and we had to have all of our
programming changes done
in order to start meeting that quarter's
filing deadlines
but this is a global phenomenon we had
changes i think we had over 2 000
regulatory changes
in over 60 countries around the world as
governments
everywhere were responding rapidly to
the pandemic and in many cases using
employers
as a channel to help provide relief to
their their workers their employees and
those clients
in turn turned to us as their provider
to help distribute that relief
so it's quite an unprecedented time don
can you tell us
a bit about what role aws cloud has
played
in your technology transformation and
helping you respond to this space of
change
yeah it's really in two phases you know
one is i talked about
the the volume of changes that we saw
and the other is speed so on the volume
side you know if we're running uh all of
a sudden we have this huge
spike in activity uh in one case again
driven by
clients who are scrambling so that they
could
access our systems and information to

for these loans so having that elastic

scale
up and down as the as the
act level of customer activity was
reaching uh unprecedented levels
was quite an advantage for us um and
then the other was was on the speed
front so
as we think about some of the new uh

to help our clients manage through

you know of course we're deploying those

not having to stand up our own

not having to go out and go through

you know we're talking about having to

in a matter of days or weeks and be able
to do so
with a capacity to enable unprecedented

unpredictable levels because nobody
really
knew or understood what the impact was
going to be
in incredible incredible in terms of

uh to respond to the changes that are

while also dealing with changes to make

uh remains productive and available as
